did.unittitle: Mandy Carter papers 1970-2013
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Mandy Carter is a self-described "southern out black lesbian social justice activist." Since 1968 she has been involved in peace, social, racial and LGBT organizing at the local, state, regional, and national levels. She has been based in Durham, N.C., since 1982. The Mandy Carter Papers span the dates 1970 to 2013 and include files related to her work as a grassroots organizer and multi-issue social justice activist.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: However, collection may contain materials to which the Acknowledgment of Legal Responsibilities and Privacy Rights form applies. Patrons must sign this form before using this collection.
Also, all or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. Consequently, there may be a 24-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Mandy Carter is a self-described "southern out black lesbian social justice activist." Since 1968, she has been involved in peace, social, racial and LGBT organizing at the local, state, regional, and national levels. She has been based in Durham, N.C., since 1982.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Mandy Carter Papers span the dates 1970 to 2013 and include files related to her work as a grassroots organizer and multi-issue social justice activist, with particular emphasis on peace activism, women's music and culture, and African American and LGBT issues.

The collection is arranged into the following series: Organizations and Major Projects, Gigs and Events, Administrative Files, and Subject Files. The Organizations and Projects Series (130 boxes) includes files from organizations and projects with which Carter was closely involved. The series is divided into subseries according to organization or project: Bread & Roses, War Resisters League, Ladyslipper, Inc., National Lesbian Conference, Association of Women's Music and Culture Conference, North Carolina Senate Vote '90, Real Women Productions, Rhythm Fest, Human Rights Campaign, North Carolina Mobilization '96, Democratic National Committee, National Black Lesbian & Gay Leadership Forum (including Equal Partners in Faith), Ad Hoc Committee for an Open Process, Floridians Representing Equity and Equality, Florida Vote/Equal Voice, Freedom to Marry Project, Southerners on New Ground, Old Lesbians Organizing for Change Conference, National Black Justice Coalition, and Other Organizations and Projects. The Gigs and Events Series (107 boxes) includes a day-by-day account of Carter's work as a multi-issue activist through files documenting her speaking engagements and attendance at conferences, rallies, marches, retreats, meetings, and other types of gatherings. The bulk of the Administrative Files Series (23 boxes) includes communications and mixed materials from affinity groups, and the Subject Files Series (4 boxes) includes a small set of files related to issues relevant to Carter's activism.
There is significant overlap across series, with Carter often filing materials related to different organizations or projects together, especially those she was involved with around the same time.
Collection was acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Projects Series, 1972-2006

scopecontent.p: Includes files from organizations and projects with which Carter was closely involved. The series is divided into subseries according to organization or project. Subseries descriptions include a broad overview of each organization or project, as well as a summary of Carter's involvement.

The series is presented in rough chronological order. Original order has been maintained to the extent possible, though dispersed materials related to a particular organization were brought together during processing. For the most part, original file folder titles were retained, though some files were combined or renamed for clarification purposes and unfoldered materials were integrated during processing.

Due to the overlapping nature of her work, Carter often filed materials related to different organizations or projects together, especially those she was involved with around the same time. As a result, materials related to organizations and projects below may also be found in the Gigs and Events Series and the Administrative Files Series.

did.unittitle: Bread & Roses Subseries, 1979-1982

scopecontent.p: Bread & Roses is a non-profit organization based in California that brings free, live entertainment to people who live in institutions. From 1979 to 1982, Carter served as the front of house volunteer coordinator for the annual Festival of Music.
Includes materials related to the logistics of organizing volunteer ushers, such as volunteer lists, schedules, assignments, meeting notes, and maps, as well as some promotional materials.

did.unittitle: Bread & Roses files
War Resisters League Subseries, 1972-2002

scopecontent.p: The War Resisters League (WRL) is a pacifist organization founded in 1923. Carter was on staff at the Western Regional Office in San Francisco, California, from October 1969 to December 1973, and served as Director of the Los Angeles office from January 1974 to December 1977. She joined the staff of the Southeast Regional Office in Durham, North Carolina, in November 1982 and worked there until December 1988.

The bulk of the material dates from Carter's time with the Southeast Regional Office (1982-1988). Local and regional actions for peace, especially in the Middle East, as well as a number of demonstrations against nuclear proliferation are documented through correspondence, meeting notes, administrative files, pamphlets, flyers and clippings. The series also includes files from WRL national and regional offices, retreats, executive and national committee meetings, as well as newsletters and reports from related organizations.

Files from the 1970s include a packet of readings on feminism and non-violence from the San Francisco office and financials from the Los Angeles office. Materials from the 1990s and 2000s include mailings to supporters and files on anniversary events in which Carter participated.

did.unittitle: WRL files
Ladyslipper, Inc. Subseries, 1988-1999

scopecontent.p: In 1989, Carter worked in wholesale distributor sales at Ladyslipper, Inc., ta distributor of women's music, with offices in Durham, North Carolina. Carter also served as a board member.

Includes files related to events, fundraising efforts, and a concert by Joan Baez one by Cris Williamson and Teresa Trull, as well as press releases, budgets, meeting notes, some correspondence, job descriptions, personnel policies, and a handful of catalogs from the 1990s. Board meeting minutes can be found in the Gigs and Events Series.

did.unittitle: Ladyslipper Music files
National Lesbian Conference Subseries, 1988-1990

scopecontent.p: The National Lesbian Conference was held April 24-28, 1991, in Atlanta, Georgia, though meetings to plan and organize the conference were held across the United States beginning in 1988. Carter helped organize the first national planning meeting held March 3-6, 1989, in Durham, North Carolina, and continued to participate in the planning process as part of the Mobilization Committee of the Interim Task Committee.

Materials document planning meetings held at the national, Southern regional, and North Carolina statewide levels as well as interim steering committee meetings in Atlanta. Includes meeting notes by Carter, as well as meeting schedules, agendas and minutes; personal and organizational letters, including updates; committee lists; and publicity, such as press releases and flyers. Pamphlets, newsletters, and other materials from LGBT organizations are interfiled.

did.unittitle: National Lesbian Conference files
Association of Women's Music and Culture Conference Subseries, 1988-1991

scopecontent.p: The Association of Women's Music and Culture (AWMAC) was an international professional organization that aimed to further the development of women's music and culture by providing services for musicians and those who created opportunities for music to reach audiences. In 1991, the AWMAC Conference was held in Durham, North Carolina, coinciding with the 15th anniversary of Ladyslipper, Inc. Carter served as Conference Coordinator and was responsible for forming a host committee to handle local logistics.

The bulk of the materials relate to preparations for the 1991 annual conference, including meeting and planning notes, flyers and promotional materials, schedules, registration materials, programs, and correspondence, as well as materials related to event venues and hotels. Also includes programs and other materials from previous conferences.

did.unittitle: AWMAC files
North Carolina Senate Vote '90 Subseries, 1990

scopecontent.p: North Carolina Senate Vote '90 (NCSV '90) was a political action committee that undertook a statewide, county-by-county lesbian, gay, and bisexual voter registration campaign in an effort to unseat Republican Senator Jesse Helms and elect Harvey Gantt, who had served as the first black mayor of Charlotte, North Carolina, from 1983 to 1987. Carter served as Campaign Manager, working on behalf of NCSV '90 for most of 1990. Carter formed a similar organization, North Carolina Mobilization '96, when Gantt challenged Helms for his Senate seat again in 1996.

Includes meeting minutes and meeting notes; planning documents, such as schedules and timelines; correspondence; office reports and updates; files related to planning events, such as fundraising benefits, rallies, and major meetings; voter registration information for counties across North Carolina and get-out-the-vote kits; materials related to fundraising and financials, including budgets, funding plans, records of pledges and donations, quarterly reports, and filings with the Federal Election Commission; designs and order forms for anti-Helms merchandise; donor lists, contact lists and mailing lists; publicity materials, including mailings, press releases, flyers for events and meetings, print ads, radio ad scripts and radio station research; files related to volunteer recruitment and organization, including sign-up forms, time logs, and schedules; and research files on both Helms and Gantt, which include media clippings, political cartoons, fundraising letters and campaign materials, voting records, and position papers.

did.unittitle: NCSV '90 files
Real Women Productions Subseries, 1986-1990

scopecontent.p: Real Women Productions existed from about 1986 to 1990. Loosely organized, it began when Mandy Carter, Lucy Harris, Cheri Sistek, and Cris South began working to bring women's entertainment and culture to Durham, North Carolina, and the surrounding areas. The group produced different types of shows, including music, comedy, and dance. Many shows were presented in conjunction with other organizations, such as Triangle Area Lesbian Feminists, the War Resisters League, and North Carolina Senate Vote '90, and often served as a fundraising mechanism with proceeds benefitting non-profit organizations in the area.

Includes materials related to the production of shows, including contracts, riders, promotional materials, correspondence, budgets and expenses, space and equipment rental agreements, and schedules, as well as correspondence regarding bookings and performances, meeting notes, related news clippings, and artist information packets and promo materials.

did.unittitle: Real Women Productions files
Rhythm Fest Subseries, 1990-1995

scopecontent.p: Rhythm Fest was a women's music, arts, and politics festival held Labor Day weekend in the South beginning in 1990. Carter was a founding co-producer of the event and served as box office coordinator from 1990 to 1994.

Materials relate to the logistics of planning the festival and include correspondence; notes from meetings and calls; receipt books; files regarding ticketing and work exchanges; promotional materials, such as flyers, pamphlets, mailings, and clippings of paid advertisements; and evaluation forms. The series also includes a small number of materials from other women's festivals.

did.unittitle: Rhythm Fest files
Human Rights Campaign Subseries,1990-2001

scopecontent.p: Founded in 1980, the Human Rights Campaign (HRC) is a national organization that advocates for LGBT equality through lobbying and grassroots organizing. Carter worked for the HRC from April 1992 through November 1995. During this time, she was the Southeast Field Coordinator, the Northern California Coordinator for the HRC Campaign '92, Public Policy Advocate for 10 Southern States Congressional Delegations, and Founder/Coordinator of A National Call to Resist: Countering the Radical Right in Our Black Community, a joint project with the National Black Lesbian and Gay Leadership Forum. She was also involved in a number of campaigns against specific anti-gay ballot measures, such as Vote No On 1 in Tampa, Fla.

Materials reflect involvement in the projects listed above and include meeting notes; training materials from workshops; conference materials and packets; mailing lists; communications, including mail, memos, email, and faxes; internal reports, including monthly reports from the Public Policy Department and reports from Board of Directors meetings; informational materials distributed by HRC, such as newsletters, mailings, press releases, action alerts, pamphlets, one-sheets, and house party packets; subject files, including materials on gay men and lesbians in the military, the Employment Non-Discrimination Act, anti-gay sentiment and actions, and the religious right; clippings; and research files on legislative activities and Members of Congress, including legislative reports and voting records.

did.unittitle: HRC files
North Carolina Mobilization '96 Subseries, 1990-1997

scopecontent.p: North Carolina Mobilization '96 (NC Mobe) was a political action committee that led a grassroots effort to mobilize North Carolina's lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and ally voters, volunteers, and money to defeat Senator Jesse Helms and elect Harvey Gantt. This was the second time Gantt challenged Helms for his seat in the United States Senate. The first time was in 1990, and Carter had led a similar organization, North Carolina Senate Vote '90, to unseat Helms and support Gantt. Carter founded the organization and served as campaign manager, working with NC Mobe for much of 1996.

Includes meeting materials and notes; planning documents, such as calendars and work plans; communications, including correspondence, email and phone messages; office reports and updates; materials related to financials and fundraising, including filings with the Federal Election Commission; files related to volunteer recruitment, orientation, and training; publicity materials, including mailings, press releases, print ads and inserts, and flyers for events and meeting; pages printed from the NC Mobe website; get-out-the-vote kits; research files on North Carolina, including voter guidelines; orders for anti-Helms merchandise; donor lists, contact lists and mailing lists; clippings; research files on both Helms and Gantt; and materials from other anti-Helms groups.

did.unittitle: NC Mobe '96 files
Democratic National Committee Subseries, 1992-2001

scopecontent.p: From May to June 1996, Carter was a consultant to the Office of Lesbian and Gay Outreach of the Democratic National Committee (DNC). In this role, she worked with existing gay and lesbian democratic clubs around the country to organize voter registration drives in their own communities. From 1996 to 2000, Carter served as a North Carolina Member-At-Large of the DNC. During this time she was involved with the Gay and Lesbian Caucus and the Black Caucus. She was also a delegate for Al Gore at the Democratic National Convention in 2000.

Includes memos and other communications, meeting agendas and notes, and briefings and reports from both caucuses, as well as files from DNC meetings and communications regarding the Gore presidential campaign. Also includes files related to the 2000 Democratic National Convention.

did.unittitle: DNC files
National Black Lesbian and Gay Leadership Forum Subseries, 1992-1999

scopecontent.p: Founded in 1988, the National Black Lesbian and Gay Leadership Forum (NBLGLF) worked to empower black lesbians, gay men, bisexuals, and transgender people by developing their leadership skills, increasing visibility, and bringing communities together. The organization disbanded in 2003. While on staff at the HRC, Carter worked in conjunction with the NBLGLF on joint projects, such as the People of Color Summit and A National Call to Resist: Countering the Radical Right in Our Black Community. Carter also worked as National Field Director of the NBLGLF from March 1997 to March 1998 and as Field Program Consultant from August 1998 to December 1998.

Includes research files, primarily clippings, on the radical right; articles about or written by Carter; work plans and budgets for the National Field Program, including work plans for specific cities (Denver, Washington, D.C., Charlotte); communications, including emails, faxes, and letters; mailings and materials for the Board of Directors; speeches; meeting notes; contracts and files related to fundraising, budgets, and donors; and records related to the annual conference.

Materials related to joint projects by the HRC and NBLGLF can be found in both subseries. People of Color Summit materials in this subseries include registration forms, materials for summit packets, clippings, press releases, and meeting notes.

did.unittitle: NBLGLF files
Equal Partners in Faith Subseries, 1996-1998

scopecontent.p: Equal Partners in Faith was a multiracial grassroots coalition of people of faith committed to equality and diversity. The coalition coordinated a response to "Stand in the Gap: A Sacred Assembly of Men," a rally held on October 4, 1997, in Washington, D.C., by the Promise Keepers, an evangelical Christian men's-only movement associated with the religious right. In the fall of 1997, Carter was on special assignment from the NBLGLF, serving as Program Director for Equal Partners in Faith.

Includes research files on Promise Keepers, primarily clippings and printed website pages; meeting notes; communications, including memos, emails, faxes, and phone messages; media plans; files related to events; contact lists; and funding proposals.

did.unittitle: Equal Partners in Faith files
Ad Hoc Committee for an Open Process Subseries, 1998-2000

scopecontent.p: Carter was a member of the Ad Hoc Committee for an Open Process, which formed in response to what members saw as a poorly conceived and non-inclusive planning process for the Millennium March on Washington, an event organized by the HRC and Metropolitan Community Churches to raise awareness and visibility of LGBT people and issues. It was held April 28-April 30, 2000 in Washington, D.C.. Previously, Carter served on the National Steering Committee for the March on Washington in 1987 and 1993.

Includes communications, such as emails, letters, and faxes; notes from meetings and conference calls; prepared letters and statements, including drafts; media clippings; and files related to meetings in Boston, New York, and Pittsburgh.

did.unittitle: Ad Hoc Committee files
Floridians Representing Equity and Equality Subseries, 1993-2000

scopecontent.p: Floridians Representing Equity and Equality (FREE) was an organization founded in 1997 and based in Tampa, Florida, that rolled out a statewide educational campaign to stop an anti-affirmative action ballot measure. Carter served as Campaign Manager from February 2000 to July 2000.

Includes public relations materials, such as flyers, pamphlets, reports, media packages, press releases and speaker requests; contact lists; and correspondence, including emails and faxes. Also includes a set of chronological folders that document Carter's activities and meetings on behalf of FREE, including preparations for the March on Tallahassee. The chronological files often include correspondence leading up to a meeting or event, notes from it, and other related materials. A list of these folders can be found in the Gigs and Events Series.

Carter spent the second half of 2000 in Florida working for Florida Vote/Equal Voice. As a result, materials related to each are sometimes interfiled, as are materials related to the Gore 2000 campaign.

did.unittitle: FREE files
Florida Vote/Equal Voice Subseries, 2000-2001

scopecontent.p: Florida Vote/Equal Voice was a non-partisan voter education, voter registration, and voter participation program that focused on Florida's African American communities. The campaign was initiated by the African American Ministries Leadership Council of the People for the American Way Foundation and the Florida State Chapter of the NAACP. The campaign was run in conjunction with Arrive With Five, a statewide voter mobilization program. Carter served as Campaign Manager from August 2000 to December 2000.

Includes communications, such as emails and faxes; contact lists; program descriptions; schedules; profiles of target counties and cities; press clippings; and campaign materials and ephemera. Also includes a set of chronological folders that document Carter's activities and meetings on behalf of Florida Vote/Equal Voice, which typically contain correspondence leading up to a meeting or event, notes from it, and other related materials. A list of these folders can be found in the Gigs and Events Series.

Carter spent the first half of 2000 in Florida working for Floridians Representing Equity and Equality. As a result, materials related to each are sometimes interfiled, as are materials related to the Gore 2000 campaign.

did.unittitle: Florida Vote/Equal Voice files
Freedom to Marry Project Subseries, 2001-2002

scopecontent.p: Based in Boston, Massachusetts, the Freedom to Marry Project was a marriage equality organization founded by civil rights attorney Evan Wolfson. Carter served as a consultant to the organization from September 2001 to January 2002.

Includes training manuals, contact lists and reports, research files on related organizations and efforts, meeting and phone call notes, emails and other communications, testimonies in opposition to House Bill 3375, Carter's contract, and ephemera. Also includes a set of files which trace her meetings, activities and travels on behalf of the organization. These often include correspondence leading up to a meeting or event, as well as notes from it, and other related materials. A list of these folders can be found in the Gigs and Events Series.

did.unittitle: Freedom to Marry Project files
Southerners on New Ground Subseries, 1993-2006

scopecontent.p: Founded in 1993, Southerners on New Ground (SONG) is a membership-based organization that aims to build a progressive movement across the South by developing transformative models of organizing that connect race, class, culture, gender, and sexuality. Carter is one of six co-founders of SONG, along with Joan Garner, Pat Hussain, Pam McMichael, Suzanne Pharr, and Mab Segrest. Carter also served as Executive Director from 2003 to 2005.

Includes meeting notes and notes from Board of Directors calls; to-do lists; annual reports; communications, especially emails; files related to fundraising and financials, including budgets and fund appeals; program reports; materials related to women's retreats organized by SONG; files related to particular projects, including ones in Mississippi and Kentucky; and issues of SONG Notes, the organization's newsletter.

did.unittitle: SONG files
Old Lesbians Organizing for Change Subseries, 2002-2006

scopecontent.p: Old Lesbians Organizing for Change (OLOC) was founded in 1989 to confront ageism within communities and to build a support network for lesbians 60 and over. OLOC's 5th National Conference was held August 17-20, 2006, in Durham, North Carolina. Carter served as a member of the host committee and was primarily responsible for organizing volunteers. She was also a keynote speaker at the event.

Includes materials related to planning the conference, such as correspondence, notes from meetings and phone calls, to-do lists, contact lists, files related to volunteers and scheduling, promotional pamphlets and flyers, and clippings. Also includes the conference program and other materials from the conference itself, as well as issues of Reporter, OLOC's newsletter.

did.unittitle: OLOC files
National Black Justice Coalition Subseries, 2003-2004

scopecontent.p: Founded in December 2003, the National Black Justice Coalition (NBJC) is a civil rights organization dedicated to empowering black LGBT people and fostering equality by fighting racism and homophobia. Carter is a founding board member, and as of 2013, she serves on the Leadership Advisory Council.

Includes materials from board meetings, such as agendas, notes, and budgets; and communications, such as email and memos. A majority of the materials relate to marriage equality, including press releases, statements, and fact sheets for a press conference on African American support for the issue.

did.unittitle: NBJC files
Other Organizations and Projects Subseries, 1981-2005

scopecontent.p: Includes files related to other organizations and projects Carter was in contact with or collected materials about. In some cases, Carter was involved as a volunteer, though typically in a more limited way than organizations appearing as their own subseries.
Materials vary, but folders often include promotional items, such as pamphlets and flyers, newsletters, reports and updates, and fundraising appeals.

Arranged in batches alphabetically and described below in an integrated alphabetical list. Organizations A-P appearing in Boxes 75 through 78 remain in their original order; other folders were assembled during processing.
Similar types of materials, including some from organizations listed below, can be found in a group of folders that include mixed materials from affinity groups in the Administrative Files Series.

Gigs and Events Series, 1979-2013

scopecontent.p: A day-by-day account of Carter's work as a multi-issue activist, this series includes files documenting her speaking engagements and attendance at conferences, rallies, marches, retreats, meetings, and other types of gatherings.

Materials vary, but files typically include correspondence, such as emails, faxes, and memos leading up to a meeting or event; promotional materials, including mailings, advertisements, and clippings; items from the event itself, such as notes, schedules, meeting agendas, and information packets; as well as LGBT publications and pamphlets for local, related, or attending organizations. Occasionally, outlines or the full text of speeches are included. Materials that were weeded during processing include travel receipts and reimbursement forms, travel documents and tickets, area maps and brochures, and national news publications.

Arranged chronologically, with materials related to preparations for an event filed according to when the event occurred. For the most part, original order has been maintained, though many of the files from the 1980s and early 1990s were brought together during processing. Original folder titles have been retained, though loose materials were foldered and given titles following conventions established by Carter.

There is significant overlap with the Organizations and Projects Series. Some materials filed here are related to organizations represented in the Organizations and Projects Series, and some of the files listed here are physically filed within the Organizations and Projects Series to maintain original order.

Administrative Files Series, 1970-2007

scopecontent.p: Includes communications, such as mail, faxes, email, and call slips; contact lists and mailing lists; notes and notebooks; to-do lists; resource lists; biographical materials, such as resumes, photographs, press clippings and publications in which Carter appears; materials related to awards Carter has received; and mixed materials from affinity groups. The bulk of the mixed materials from affinity groups arrived loose and were foldered during processing; they typically include promotional materials, pamphlets, fundraising appeals, updates and reports, promotional materials, and informational packets. Very occasionally they include correspondence of a more personal nature or notes from meetings or events.

Files were assembled during processing and are arranged chronologically within groupings. Original folder titles have been retained, though loose materials were foldered and labeled during processing.

In terms of overlap, the communications files and the mixed materials from affinity groups include items related to organizations and projects represented in the Organizations and Major Projects Series, including the Other Organizations Subseries.

scopecontent.p: Includes a small set of files related to issues relevant to Carter's activism, including a set of files related to African American politicians and organizations.
Arranged alphabetically. For the most part, materials were assembled during processing, though the African American files in Box 261 remain in their original order.
